Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: Evaluating Form-Function-Fitness Relationships in Polyphenic Bluegill
Award.AbstractNarration:
Locomotion and feeding are essential behaviors for the survival and reproductive fitness of most animals. However, little is understood about why some individuals within a population outperform others and are better suited to their habitat. Populations of bluegill sunfish often diverge into two different body forms based on their habitat: a deeper-bodied shallow water form or a streamlined deep water form. This variation creates an ideal system for investigating the relationships between form, function and adaptation to habitat.

This project will integrate studies of behavior in the field, external and internal morphology and muscle physiology, energy metabolism, swimming performance, feeding mechanics and fitness measurements in order to quantify variation in swimming and feeding performance within a single population of bluegill from pelagic and littoral habitats. Results from this research will provide unprecedented insight into the complex interrelationships of body form, swimming and feeding performance and fitness in fish. Moreover, this research will provide an experimental and analytical framework that could be applied to any animal system. This proposal is a collaborative effort among three liberal arts institutions, therefore an important component of the project will be the mentoring of a postdoctoral researcher and the training of undergraduates, a high proportion of whom will continue their education in graduate or professional schools, increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences. The research will be implemented in an outreach program aimed to introduce basic concepts of biomechanics and physiology to underrepresented K-12 students at neighboring schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Locomotion and feeding are essential behaviors for the survival and reproductive fitness of most animals. However, little is understood about why some individuals within a population have increased performance compared to others and are better suited to their habitat. Populations of bluegills (Lepomis macrochirus) often diverge into two body forms based on their habitat: a deeper-bodied shallow water form or a streamlined deep water form. This variation created an ideal system for investigating the relationships between form, function and adaptation to habitat. This collaborative project integrated studies of behavior in the field, external and internal morphology and muscle physiology, energy metabolism, swimming performance, feeding mechanics and fitness measurements in order to quantify variation in swimming and feeding performance within a single population of bluegills from pelagic and littoral habitats. We found that littoral and pelagic bluegills show similar kinematics and generate similar negative pressure when feeding. However, within a body form, pelagic bluegills used the same approach behavior regardless of the type of prey offered. More notably bluegills (littoral and pelagic) feed differently in the wild as compared to the lab. Fish feed with greater suction pressure in the field; therefore, laboratory studies may underestimate performance variables. We are continuing our analysis of the physiology and mechanics of the swimming muscles as well as understanding how our findings relate to the overall fitness of each body form.

Equipment from this award also provided an opportunity to study the effects of temperature on the feeding performance, swimming performance and muscle physiology of cunner and tautog, two local species of fish from Long Island Sound. We found that escape velocities and steady swimming slowed at lower temperatures. Muscle fibers also contracted more slowly. Cunner and tautog used different feeding behaviors when feeding at colder temperatures as compared to warm.

Broader Impacts: Eight publications have resulted from this research and data has been collected to write another seven. Twenty talks or conference posters were presented at regional, national or international meetings as well as two invited University seminars. Seventeen undergraduates earned research credit and/or received summer stipends from this award. Additionally, a postdoctoral researcher was supported for three years. Over three summers, the PI and six undergraduates mentored 12 female high school students from underrepresented groups as part of Broadening Access to Science Education (BASE) Camp. Second-grade students at a neighboring elementary school observed a fish dissection each year.
